div.head: William and Edward Francis Finden
div.p: Engravers, based in London. The brothers worked jointly, overseeing a large workshop employing many assistants and pupils of the trade. They specialized in landscape, although they also undertook many portraits. William's achievements in steel-engraving include the vignettes after Stothard for Samuel Rogers's Italy (1830) and Rogers's Poems (1834), complementing Edward Goodall's work after Turner for those volumes. Edward's well-known works include the plates for William Brockedon's Illustrations of the Passes of the Alps (1827-29). The brothers enjoyed a long relationship with the firm of John Murray, for example contributing significantly to the 1841 edition of Byron's Childe Harold's Pilgrimage.

The Findens attempted publishing in their own right, issuing for example Finden's Landscape Illustrations to Mr. Murray's First Complete and Uniform Edition of the Life and Works of Lord Byron (1832-34). Because these projects proved so ambitious, however, the brothers ultimately relied on collaborations with other publishers. Such was the case, for example, with Finden's Landscape Illustrations to the Bible (1834-37).
Hunnisett, Steel‐Engraved Book Illustration in England, 84–95.
